intro: Selinum carvifolia-linnaei, commonly known as the lesser calamint, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodland areas. Its aromatic foliage contains compounds that have been used in traditional herbal medicine.
